elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived nanomaterials provide outstanding catalytic activities for CO2 electroreduction due to their large surface area, tunable geometric structures, and controllable pore size. Herein, we develop a Cu/Cu2O nanocomposite loaded on the surface of carbon derived from direct carbonization of two-dimensional cross-like zeolitic imidazolate framework-L coated vertically on graphene oxide (Cu GNC-VL). The as-synthesized catalyst presented an excellent faradaic efficiency of 70.52% and current density of 10.4 mA cm–2 at −0.87 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode, which benefits from the synergy between CO2 asymmetric chemical adsorption on Cu(111) and favorable kinetics and thermodynamics of C–C coupling on Cu2O­(111). This study presents a strategy for the rational design and multiple-pathway modulation of the geometry structure of MOF-derived catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Metal–organic
framework (MOF)-derived nanomaterials provide
outstanding catalytic activities for CO2 electroreduction
due to their large surface area, tunable geometric structures, and
controllable pore size. Herein, we develop a Cu/Cu2O nanocomposite
loaded on the surface of carbon derived from direct carbonization
of two-dimensional cross-like zeolitic imidazolate framework-L coated
vertically on graphene oxide (Cu GNC-VL). The as-synthesized catalyst
presented an excellent faradaic efficiency of 70.52% and current density
of 10.4 mA cm–2 at −0.87 V versus the reversible
hydrogen electrode, which benefits from the synergy between CO2 asymmetric chemical adsorption on Cu(111) and favorable kinetics
and thermodynamics of C–C coupling on Cu2O­(111).
This study presents a strategy for the rational design and multiple-pathway
modulation of the geometry structure of MOF-derived catalysts.

elements.content: Electrochemical reduction of CO2 to fossil fuels or high-value-added chemicals has grown into a promising research topic passed through several dozen years of development because it provides a cost-effective and sustainable pathway to deal with this greenhouse gas. Among the various reduction products, C2 hydrocarbons and oxygenates are highly energy-efficient owing to their high energy densities and are in demand. C2H5OH, as a substitute for automotive fuel, is also developed into a potential alternative for conventional batteries. Nevertheless, the systematic work on various intermediates in the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to hydrocarbons by Koper and co-workers demonstrates that the dimerization of *CO is the rate-determining step (RDS) for C2 formation with a more positive onset potential shift, further proving that *CO dimerization may occur. In particular, Cu-based catalysts are deemed the most likely to directly reduce CO2 to hydrocarbons and alcohols by intense C–C coupling. The theoretical evidence of the CO dimerization mechanism shows that Cu-based catalysts decrease sharply the thermodynamic and kinetic energy of CO dimerization for enhancing the electroreduction of CO2 to C2 products. However, most of these Cu-based catalysts still exhibit low selectivity and faradaic efficiency for alcohol production in aqueous solution due to the various lattice planes, defects, or vacancies of polycrystalline and oxidized Cu. Hence, product selectivity of Cu-based catalysts is mainly determined by adjusting the oxidation states, vacancies, geometric structure, and morphologies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Electrochemical reduction
of CO2 to fossil fuels or
high-value-added chemicals has grown into a promising research topic
passed through several dozen years of development because it provides
a cost-effective and sustainable pathway to deal with this greenhouse
gas. Among the various reduction products, C2 hydrocarbons
and oxygenates are highly energy-efficient owing to their high energy
densities and are in demand. C2H5OH,
as a substitute for automotive fuel, is also developed into a potential
alternative for conventional batteries. Nevertheless, the systematic
work on various intermediates in the CO2 reduction reaction
(CO2RR) to hydrocarbons by Koper and co-workers demonstrates
that the dimerization of *CO is the rate-determining step (RDS) for
C2 formation with a more positive onset potential shift,
further proving that *CO dimerization may occur. In particular, Cu-based catalysts are deemed the most likely to
directly reduce CO2 to hydrocarbons and alcohols by intense
C–C coupling. The theoretical evidence of the
CO dimerization mechanism shows that Cu-based catalysts decrease sharply
the thermodynamic and kinetic energy of CO dimerization for enhancing
the electroreduction of CO2 to C2 products. However, most of these Cu-based catalysts still exhibit low selectivity
and faradaic efficiency for alcohol production in aqueous solution
due to the various lattice planes, defects, or vacancies of polycrystalline
and oxidized Cu. Hence, product selectivity
of Cu-based catalysts is mainly determined by adjusting the oxidation
states, vacancies, geometric structure, and morphologies.

elements.content: It is worth noting that crystalline Cu-based catalysts are sought enthusiastically by many researchers, but the amorphous ones with abundant defects and more active sites are less explored. Among the various potential amorphous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as kinds of hybrid crystalline are also attractive because of their high specific surface areas and increased catalytic active sites in gas adsorption and separation and molecular catalysis. In addition, amorphous Cu derived from carbonization of MOFs affects the catalyst structure, weakening the van der Waals interaction between the ligands to generate abundant active sites and increasing the band gap for enhanced semiconductivity. As catalyst candidates, their open channel ensures the adsorption of carbon dioxide molecules in the pore and the diffusion of reduction products along with a tunable channel with minimized mass-transfer resistance. Nevertheless, a realistic problem is that porous MOFs usually act as electrical insulators. Therefore, MOFs are often compounded with other nanosemiconductor materials such as graphene oxide (GO) and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to increase the conductivity and facilitate electron transfer of CO2RR. In addition, postcarbonization treatment of MOF-derived graphene-based N-doped porous carbon nanocomposites (GNPCNs) is needed to increase the electrochemical performance of CO2. However, directly carbonized MOFs will result in a breakdown of the open framework structure of MOFs because of their thermal instability and cannot construct a continuous conductive medium. Consequently, the reaction mechanism of CO2 electroreduction is so hard to keep integrated at the complicated three-phase interface (solid–liquid–gas) on a heterogeneous catalyst in which the rational design of a geometric structure of the catalyst occupied an important position. Naturally, anchoring MOFs on GO converted to GNPCNs by calcination could be a promotional alternative to exert the synergistic effect between MOF-derived N-doped porous carbon (NPC) and GO-derived graphene in CO2 electroreduction because MOFs undergoing postcarbonization treatment are transformed into amorphous carbonaceous materials with many low-coordinated atoms. The development of a facile and effective strategy for the preparation of dispersive GO/MOF nanosheets with a uniform and complete MOF coating toward efficient Cu/Cu2O-loaded GNPCN precursors is repeated several times. However, two-dimensional oriented GO/MOF nanocomposites for the CO2 electroreduction has seldom been studied.
elements.clean_text:
It is worth noting that
crystalline Cu-based catalysts are sought
enthusiastically by many researchers, but the amorphous ones with
abundant defects and more active sites are less explored. Among the various potential amorphous materials, metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs) as kinds of hybrid crystalline are also attractive
because of their high specific surface areas and increased catalytic
active sites in gas adsorption and separation and molecular catalysis. In addition, amorphous Cu derived from carbonization of MOFs affects
the catalyst structure, weakening the van der Waals interaction between
the ligands to generate abundant active sites and increasing the band
gap for enhanced semiconductivity. As catalyst
candidates, their open channel ensures the adsorption of carbon dioxide
molecules in the pore and the diffusion of reduction products along
with a tunable channel with minimized mass-transfer resistance. Nevertheless, a realistic problem is that porous MOFs usually act
as electrical insulators. Therefore, MOFs are often compounded with
other nanosemiconductor materials such as graphene oxide (GO) and
carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to increase the conductivity and facilitate
electron transfer of CO2RR. In addition, postcarbonization treatment of MOF-derived
graphene-based N-doped porous carbon nanocomposites (GNPCNs) is needed
to increase the electrochemical performance of CO2. However, directly carbonized MOFs will result in
a breakdown of the open framework structure of MOFs because of their
thermal instability and cannot construct a continuous conductive medium.
Consequently, the reaction mechanism of CO2 electroreduction
is so hard to keep integrated at the complicated three-phase interface
(solid–liquid–gas) on a heterogeneous catalyst in which
the rational design of a geometric structure of the catalyst occupied
an important position. Naturally, anchoring MOFs on
GO converted to GNPCNs by calcination could be a promotional alternative
to exert the synergistic effect between MOF-derived N-doped porous
carbon (NPC) and GO-derived graphene in CO2 electroreduction
because MOFs undergoing postcarbonization treatment are transformed
into amorphous carbonaceous materials with many low-coordinated atoms. The development of a facile and effective strategy for the preparation
of dispersive GO/MOF nanosheets with a uniform and complete MOF coating
toward efficient Cu/Cu2O-loaded GNPCN precursors is repeated
several times. However, two-dimensional oriented
GO/MOF nanocomposites for the CO2 electroreduction has
seldom been studied.

elements.content: Zeolitic imidazolate framework-L (ZIF-L), a two-dimensional pseudopolymorph of ZIF-8, has widely used in gas separation and sensing, dye adsorption, and energy storage due to its regular porous structure and chemical and thermal stability. In this work, we prepared oriented ZIF-L-derived GO nanosheets by vertical growth of ZIF-L on GO (vZIF-L@GO), introducing a copper precursor into the top mesoporous supporting layer followed by carbonization at 1000 °C for 2 h. The as-prepared Cu GNC-VL catalyst generated a three-dimensional geometric structure that furnished abundant active site and efficient electronic conductivity. Cu GNC-VL achieved a high FEethanol of 70.52% at the total current density of 10.4 mA cm–2 in 0.5 M KHCO3 solution. Ultimately, these results demonstrate that the development of a simple and effective methodology for preparing Cu GNC-VL nanocomposites with a uniform and oriented MOF coating toward efficient CO2RR is worthy to explore.
elements.clean_text:
Zeolitic imidazolate framework-L (ZIF-L),
a two-dimensional pseudopolymorph
of ZIF-8, has widely used in gas separation and sensing, dye adsorption,
and energy storage due to its regular porous structure and chemical
and thermal stability. In this work, we prepared oriented ZIF-L-derived
GO nanosheets by vertical growth of ZIF-L on GO (vZIF-L@GO), introducing
a copper precursor into the top mesoporous supporting layer followed
by carbonization at 1000 °C for 2 h. The as-prepared Cu GNC-VL
catalyst generated a three-dimensional geometric structure that furnished
abundant active site and efficient electronic conductivity. Cu GNC-VL
achieved a high FEethanol of 70.52% at the total current
density of 10.4 mA cm–2 in 0.5 M KHCO3 solution. Ultimately, these results demonstrate that the development
of a simple and effective methodology for preparing Cu GNC-VL nanocomposites
with a uniform and oriented MOF coating toward efficient CO2RR is worthy to explore.

elements.content: The leaf-shaped ZIF-L, with a 2D topology containing large zero-dimensional cavities with dimensions of 9.4 Å × 7.0 Å × 5.3 Å (Figure S1a), is constructed of identical building blocks of ZIF-8 Hmim linkers and Zn2+ ions in deionized water at room temperature. It exhibits uniform flake-like and intergrown crystallites with an average size of 300 nm (Figure S4a). The ZIF-L within the flake in the ac plane presents six-membered rings comprised of tetrahedral Zn2+ clusters and Hmim linkers (Figure S2), and each Zn atom adopts a regular [ZnN4] tetrahedral geometry. In addition, the 2D network is further stabilized by the interdigitating interactions with the help of the terminal Hmim ligands. The hydrogen bond exists between adjacent Hmim, and a weak interaction of the neighboring layers confirms that the vertical GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites were successfully synthesized by simple synthesis methods. It not only benefits from the mutual support between the cross-like ZIF-L crystallites but also relies on the chelation of Zn ions with oxygen-containing functional groups (OCFGs) of GO, including carboxyl, epoxide, carbonyl, and hydroxyl groups.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
The leaf-shaped
ZIF-L, with a 2D topology containing large zero-dimensional
cavities with dimensions of 9.4 Å × 7.0 Å × 5.3
Å (Figure S1a), is constructed of
identical building blocks of ZIF-8 Hmim linkers and Zn2+ ions in deionized water at room temperature. It exhibits uniform flake-like and intergrown crystallites
with an average size of 300 nm (Figure S4a). The ZIF-L within the flake in the ac plane presents
six-membered rings comprised of tetrahedral Zn2+ clusters
and Hmim linkers (Figure S2), and each
Zn atom adopts a regular [ZnN4] tetrahedral geometry. In
addition, the 2D network is further stabilized by the interdigitating
interactions with the help of the terminal Hmim ligands. The hydrogen bond exists between adjacent Hmim,
and a weak interaction of the neighboring layers confirms that the
vertical GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites were successfully synthesized by
simple synthesis methods. It not only benefits from the mutual support
between the cross-like ZIF-L crystallites but also relies on the chelation
of Zn ions with oxygen-containing functional groups (OCFGs) of GO,
including carboxyl, epoxide, carbonyl, and hydroxyl groups.

other properties: flake-like and intergrown crystallites with an average size of 300 nm
six-membered rings comprised of tetrahedral Zn2+ clusters and Hmim linkers
each Zn atom adopts a regular [ZnN4] tetrahedral geometry
2D network is further stabilized by the interdigitating interactions with the help of the terminal Hmim ligands
hydrogen bond exists between adjacent Hmim
weak interaction of the neighboring layers
vertical GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites were successfully synthesized by simple synthesis methods
benefits from the mutual support between the cross-like ZIF-L crystallites
relies on the chelation of Zn ions with oxygen-containing functional groups (OCFGs) of GO, including carboxyl, epoxide, carbonyl, and hydroxyl groups

elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns (Figure S1b) showed the complete crystal pattern of ZIF-L and GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites, indicating the successful growth of ZIF-L on the GO surface and special vertical distribution of the complete vZIF-L@GO crystal. This was also supported by the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of ZIF-L@GO (Figure S4b) and vZIF-L@GO (b,c). The 633 nm excited Raman spectra (Figure S3a) of ZIF-L@GO and vZIF-L@GO presented two Raman bands at 1345 and 1590 cm–1, and the similar intensity implied obtained composites of GO/ZIF-L showing completely vertical structure and less defects, which reflected the more coordinated growth of ZIF-L on GO. The pyrolysis of ZIF-L and GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites was clearly analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S1d). At 300 °C, the weakly linked Hmim and water molecule were removed from the as-synthesized samples. The distinctive weight loss at about 650 °C was attributed to graphitization of GO with OCFGs participating in the linker decomposition. The evaporation of Zn clusters began to dominate the weight loss with the temperature increased to greater than 800 °C, which resulted from the low boiling point (907 °C) of Zn, leaving the N-rich defects. However, the slight advantage of thermal stability (above 800 °C) of vZIF-L@GO confirmed that the weak interactions and hydrogen bonding among the vertical ZIF-L played a positive role for exerting a synergistic effect of GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites. In addition, the adsorption properties of vZIF-L@GO were analyzed by N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (Figure S1c). The type IV isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop indicated that the mesopores might originate from the porous ZIF-L and graphene sheets. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area showed that vZIF-L@GO (604 m2/g) has a surface area higher than that of ZIF-L@GO (517 m2/g). The wider hysteresis loop of the ZIF-L@GO isotherm proved that the pore blocking might be a result of disorder distribution of ZIF-L on GO and the accumulation of GO sheets.

X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns
(Figure S1b) showed the complete crystal pattern of ZIF-L and GO/ZIF-L
nanocomposites, indicating the successful growth of ZIF-L on the GO
surface and special vertical distribution of the complete vZIF-L@GO
crystal. This was also supported by the scanning electron microscope
(SEM) images of ZIF-L@GO (Figure S4b) and
vZIF-L@GO (b,c). The 633 nm excited Raman spectra (Figure S3a) of ZIF-L@GO and vZIF-L@GO presented two Raman bands at
1345 and 1590 cm–1, and the similar intensity implied
obtained composites of GO/ZIF-L showing completely vertical structure
and less defects, which reflected the more coordinated growth of ZIF-L
on GO. The pyrolysis of ZIF-L and GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites was clearly
analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S1d). At 300 °C, the weakly linked Hmim and water
molecule were removed from the as-synthesized samples. The distinctive
weight loss at about 650 °C was attributed to graphitization
of GO with OCFGs participating in the linker decomposition. The evaporation
of Zn clusters began to dominate the weight loss with the temperature
increased to greater than 800 °C, which resulted from the low
boiling point (907 °C) of Zn, leaving the N-rich defects. However, the slight advantage of thermal stability
(above 800 °C) of vZIF-L@GO confirmed that the weak interactions
and hydrogen bonding among the vertical ZIF-L played a positive role
for exerting a synergistic effect of GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites. In addition,
the adsorption properties of vZIF-L@GO were analyzed by N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (Figure S1c). The type IV isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop indicated
that the mesopores might originate from the porous ZIF-L and graphene
sheets. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface
area showed that vZIF-L@GO (604 m2/g) has a surface area
higher than that of ZIF-L@GO (517 m2/g). The wider hysteresis
loop of the ZIF-L@GO isotherm proved that the pore blocking might
be a result of disorder distribution of ZIF-L on GO and the accumulation
of GO sheets.

(e) High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy images and (f) SEM image of Cu GNC-VL. (g) Corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy maps reveal the homogeneous distribution of Cu and N.

1

(a) Formation of Cu GNC-VL.
(b) Surface and (c) cross-sectional
morphology SEM image of vZIF-L@GO. (d) Corresponding selected area
electron diffraction pattern. (e) High-angle annular dark-field scanning
transmission electron microscopy images and (f) SEM image of Cu GNC-VL.
(g) Corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy maps reveal the homogeneous

elements.content: A mechanism illustrating the Cu GNC-VL formation process is summarized (a). GO/ZIF-L sheets were reduced and transformed to Cu GNC-VL (f and S5c) and Cu ZIF-L@GO (Figure S5a) after the carbonization treatment. The structure and active components of catalysts were clearly tracked by the XRD pattern (a). The peak of amorphous graphite-like carbon changed significantly at 2θ = 23.6 or 43.2°, representing the interplane (002) and innerplane (110) reflections of graphite carbon, respectively. Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO presented similar characteristic peaks at 2θ = 43.07, 50.2, 73.7, 89.6, and 95°, corresponding to Cu(111), Cu(200), Cu(220), Cu(311), and Cu(222), respectively (JCPDS card no. 04-0836). The special diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.3 and 61.1° exclusively belonged to the Cu2O­(111) and Cu2O­(220) residues that existed in Cu GNC-VL, respectively (JPPDS no. 78-2076). Raman spectroscopy of the carbonizations is presented in Figure S3b. The intensity ratio of the graphite-like peak (I D/I G) is related to the concentration of covalent defect sites. Hence, the relative increase of the I D/I G ratio of Cu GNC-VL (1.18) revealed the abundant defects and the suppressed graphitic degree. To demonstrate the positive effects of defects derived from mild graphitization conditions, the adsorption kinetics experiments at surfaces of catalysts were characterized in Figure S6. The type III isotherm with an H3-type hysteresis loop in N2 appeared to be an obvious difference in which the BET surface area of Cu GNC-VL was significantly enlarged, which might benefit from the abundant defects that resulted from the evaporation of Zn clusters during calcination and additional porosity between vertical ZIF-L as well as the stacking of N-doped graphene sheets, and the CO2 adsorption isotherms also confirmed that as-synthesized catalysts have a stronger force field with carbon dioxide.

A mechanism illustrating the Cu GNC-VL formation process is summarized
(a). GO/ZIF-L
sheets were reduced and transformed to Cu GNC-VL (f and S5c) and Cu ZIF-L@GO (Figure S5a) after the carbonization treatment. The structure and active components
of catalysts were clearly tracked by the XRD pattern (a). The peak of amorphous graphite-like
carbon changed significantly at 2θ = 23.6 or 43.2°, representing
the interplane (002) and innerplane (110) reflections of graphite
carbon, respectively. Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO presented
similar characteristic peaks at 2θ = 43.07, 50.2, 73.7, 89.6,
and 95°, corresponding to Cu(111), Cu(200), Cu(220), Cu(311),
and Cu(222), respectively (JCPDS card no. 04-0836). The special diffraction
peaks at 2θ = 36.3 and 61.1° exclusively belonged to the
Cu2O­(111) and Cu2O­(220) residues that existed
in Cu GNC-VL, respectively (JPPDS no. 78-2076). Raman spectroscopy
of the carbonizations is presented in Figure S3b. The intensity ratio of the graphite-like peak (I
D/I
G) is related to the concentration
of covalent defect sites. Hence, the relative increase of the I
D/I
G ratio of Cu
GNC-VL (1.18) revealed the abundant defects and the suppressed graphitic
degree. To demonstrate the positive effects of defects derived from
mild graphitization conditions, the adsorption kinetics experiments
at surfaces of catalysts were characterized in Figure S6. The type III isotherm with an H3-type hysteresis
loop in N2 appeared to be an obvious difference in which
the BET surface area of Cu GNC-VL was significantly enlarged, which
might benefit from the abundant defects that resulted from the evaporation
of Zn clusters during calcination and additional porosity between
vertical ZIF-L as well as the stacking of N-doped graphene sheets,
and the CO2 adsorption isotherms also confirmed that as-synthesized
catalysts have a stronger force field with carbon dioxide.

elements.content: The evolution of structural properties, morphology, composition, and valence state of Cu GNC-VL were investigated by electron microscopy (SEM and TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Figure S5, SEM pictures demonstrated the thermal reduction of Cu2+. During the heat treatment, Cu2+ was converted to monodispersed copper nanospheres (white spherical particles) with the polycrystalline structure. This conclusion was further demonstrated by TEM and high-resolution SEM images. Cu nanospheres were embedded in microporous N-doped porous carbon (f). Moreover, the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (g) showed that N and Cu were homogeneously distributed. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM image (e and S7a) revealed that the as-synthesized Cu GNC-VL maintained a spatial structure, and the Cu/Cu2O polycrystal presented a multilayered three-dimensional distribution. The ring-like selected area electron diffraction pattern is shown in d. The Cu(111), Cu(220), Cu(311), and Cu2O­(111) crystal planes were observed on Cu GNC-VL, whereas the crystal plane of Cu2O was absent on Cu ZIF-L@GO (Figure S7b). These observations were consistent with the XRD results, indicating that the white monodisperse copper nanospheres had similar morphology but different crystal structure. XPS was further characterized by the evolution of valence states and composition of elements. With the evaporation of volatile components, the highest content of N was observed on Cu GNC-VL (8.75 atom %), which was superior to that of the Cu ZIF-L@GO (5.91 at%) and pyrolyzed ZIF-L (5.09 at%) because its weak interaction between vertical ZIF-L prevented the decomposition of organic linkers inside ZIF-L (Table S1). Highly porous N-doped carbons originated from the inheritance of structurally irreversible defects, which were derived from the massive evaporation of Zn, N, and O, producing plenty of active sites. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra (Figure S8) were deconvoluted into three subpeaks at 398.4, 400.4, and 401.3 eV, corresponding to pyridine-like, pyrrole-like, and graphene-like nitrogen, respectively. The atomic concentrations of N allocated to pyridine-N, pyrrole-N, and graphitic-N were 45.81, 14.77, and 39.42% for Cu GNC-VL, respectively. The N-heteroatoms are considered as the active sites for decreasing adsorption energy of CO2 electroreduction, promoting following sequence: pyridine-N, pyrrole-N, pyridine-N. The total content of pyridine-like and graphene-like N of Cu GNC-VL was outmatched compared to that of pyrolyzed ZIF-L and Cu ZIF-L@GO, which not only laid a foundation for CO2RR to alcohols but also increased the conductivity of the catalysts. These results implied that Cu GNC-VL exerted a maximum synergistic effect of Cu/Cu2O-loaded vertical GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites for its defect-abundant NPC and CO2 diffusion channels as well as a consecutive conductive network toward CO2RR.
elements.clean_text:
The evolution of structural properties, morphology, composition,
and valence state of Cu GNC-VL were investigated by electron microscopy
(SEM and TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown
in Figure S5, SEM pictures demonstrated
the thermal reduction of Cu2+. During the heat treatment,
Cu2+ was converted to monodispersed copper nanospheres
(white spherical particles) with the polycrystalline structure. This
conclusion was further demonstrated by TEM and high-resolution SEM
images. Cu nanospheres were embedded in microporous N-doped porous
carbon (f).
Moreover, the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (g) showed that N
and Cu were homogeneously distributed. The high-angle annular dark-field
scanning TEM image (e and S7a) revealed that the as-synthesized
Cu GNC-VL maintained a spatial structure, and the Cu/Cu2O polycrystal presented a multilayered three-dimensional distribution.
The ring-like selected area electron diffraction pattern is shown
in d. The Cu(111),
Cu(220), Cu(311), and Cu2O­(111) crystal planes were observed
on Cu GNC-VL, whereas the crystal plane of Cu2O was absent
on Cu ZIF-L@GO (Figure S7b). These observations
were consistent with the XRD results, indicating that the white monodisperse
copper nanospheres had similar morphology but different crystal structure.
XPS was further characterized by the evolution of valence states and
composition of elements. With the evaporation of volatile components,
the highest content of N was observed on Cu GNC-VL (8.75 atom %),
which was superior to that of the Cu ZIF-L@GO (5.91 at%) and pyrolyzed
ZIF-L (5.09 at%) because its weak interaction between vertical ZIF-L
prevented the decomposition of organic linkers inside ZIF-L (Table S1). Highly porous N-doped carbons originated
from the inheritance of structurally irreversible defects, which were
derived from the massive evaporation of Zn, N, and O, producing plenty
of active sites. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra (Figure S8) were deconvoluted into three subpeaks
at 398.4, 400.4, and 401.3 eV, corresponding to pyridine-like, pyrrole-like,
and graphene-like nitrogen, respectively. The atomic concentrations of N allocated to pyridine-N, pyrrole-N,
and graphitic-N were 45.81, 14.77, and 39.42% for Cu GNC-VL, respectively.
The N-heteroatoms are considered as the active sites for decreasing
adsorption energy of CO2 electroreduction, promoting following
sequence: pyridine-N, pyrrole-N, pyridine-N. The total content of pyridine-like and graphene-like N of Cu GNC-VL
was outmatched compared to that of pyrolyzed ZIF-L and Cu ZIF-L@GO,
which not only laid a foundation for CO2RR to alcohols
but also increased the conductivity of the catalysts. These results
implied that Cu GNC-VL exerted a maximum synergistic effect of Cu/Cu2O-loaded vertical GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites for its defect-abundant
NPC and CO2 diffusion channels as well as a consecutive
conductive network toward CO2RR.

elements.content: To further determine surface composition and valence states valence states of Cu inside Cu GNC-VL, the Cu 2p XPS spectra and Cu LMM Auger spectra were measured. In c, the peaks situated at 952.2 and 932.3 eV belonged to Cu­(I)/Cu(0) species, whereas the peaks observed at 954.3 and 934.5 eV should be distributed to Cu­(II). It did indicate the existence of Cu oxides on the surface of Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO and implied low content of Cu2+ because of the disappearing satellite peaks. To distinguish the metallic Cu(0) and trace Cu­(I), the high-resolution Cu Auger LMM spectra (b,d) of Cu ZIF-L@GO and Cu GNC-VL before and after pyrolysis were analyzed. The peaks discovered at 572.4 and 572.48 eV can be assigned to Cu­(II) before pyrolysis, whereas the peaks at 569.1 and 567.88 eV should be associated with Cu­(I) and Cu(0) after pyrolysis. To prove the stability of the valence state of Cu in the catalyst, Cu Auger LMM spectra were further characterized after the optimal potential electrolysis and final electrolysis, respectively (Figure S6c,d). Though a small amount of Cu­(I) was reduced to Cu(0) with the decreased binding energy of Cu from 569.1 to approximately 568.6 eV, Cu GNC-VL still maintained the composite structure of Cu/Cu2O. For Cu ZIF-L@GO, the stability of the valence state of Cu(0) was not affected by the reduced 0.3 eV of the binding energy of Cu. Cu GNC-VL gave a broad and asymmetric peak, implying the existence of Cu­(I) and Cu(0) in a stable state. Subsequently, the calculation of the surface composition of Cu was about 0.6% in Cu GNC-VL, and the percentage content of Cu­(I) was 70.58% (Table S2). The high distribution Cu2O acted as the initiator for the dimerization of *CO, promoting the formation of C2 products. To the best of our knowledge, this catalytic behavior outperforms those of most of the reported catalysts (Table S3).

To further determine
surface composition and valence states valence
states of Cu inside Cu GNC-VL, the Cu 2p XPS spectra and Cu LMM Auger
spectra were measured. In c, the peaks situated at 952.2 and 932.3 eV belonged
to Cu­(I)/Cu(0) species, whereas the peaks observed at 954.3 and 934.5
eV should be distributed to Cu­(II). It did indicate the existence
of Cu oxides on the surface of Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO and implied
low content of Cu2+ because of the disappearing satellite
peaks. To distinguish the metallic Cu(0)
and trace Cu­(I), the high-resolution Cu Auger LMM spectra (b,d) of Cu ZIF-L@GO
and Cu GNC-VL before and after pyrolysis were analyzed. The peaks
discovered at 572.4 and 572.48 eV can be assigned to Cu­(II) before
pyrolysis, whereas the peaks at 569.1 and 567.88 eV should be associated
with Cu­(I) and Cu(0) after pyrolysis. To prove the stability of the
valence state of Cu in the catalyst, Cu Auger LMM spectra were further
characterized after the optimal potential electrolysis and final electrolysis,
respectively (Figure S6c,d). Though a small
amount of Cu­(I) was reduced to Cu(0) with the decreased binding energy
of Cu from 569.1 to approximately 568.6 eV, Cu GNC-VL still maintained
the composite structure of Cu/Cu2O. For Cu ZIF-L@GO, the
stability of the valence state of Cu(0) was not affected by the reduced
0.3 eV of the binding energy of Cu. Cu GNC-VL gave a broad and asymmetric
peak, implying the existence of Cu­(I) and Cu(0) in a stable state. Subsequently, the calculation of the surface
composition of Cu was about 0.6% in Cu GNC-VL, and the percentage
content of Cu­(I) was 70.58% (Table S2).
The high distribution Cu2O acted as the initiator for the
dimerization of *CO, promoting the formation of C2 products. To the
best of our knowledge, this catalytic behavior outperforms those of
most of the reported catalysts (Table S3).

elements.content: To investigate the electrochemical reduction reaction of CO2, a series of electrochemical tests were implemented on the cathode in an H-type electrolytic cell. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) (a and a) exhibited a more positive onset potential for Cu GNC-VL (−0.46 V vs RHE) than that of Cu ZIF-L@GO and pyrolyzed ZIF-L. The Cu contents of Cu ZIF-L@GO (0.522%) and Cu GNC-VL (0.504%) were measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy. These catalysts were measured at a similar loading but showed different catalytic activity. This result was attributed to the synergistic effect of the composite crystal structure of Cu/Cu2O nanoparticles embedded in Cu GNC-VL and the highly dispersed particle with efficient activity and uniform active sites. In b, the partial current density of ethanol reached 8.69 mA cm–2 at −0.87 V, which was larger than that of Cu and pyrolyzed ZIF-L. In addition, the relevant partial current densities of other products listed in Figure S12 also proved that Cu GNC-VL displayed higher selectivity and charge efficiency. It could be seen that Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO did exhibit excellent ability to generate hydrocarbons or alcohols and inhibit the hydrogen evolution reaction, which provided sufficient conditions for efficiently producing ethanol on Cu GNC-VL. Encouraged by the improvement of catalytic performance of CO2 electroreduction, we investigated the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the relevant reaction kinetics of pyrolyzed ZIF-L, Cu ZIF-L@GO, and Cu GNC-VL. In consideration of the fact that ECSA is positively correlated with double-layer capacitance (C dl), the C dl value was approved to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the catalysts (C and S9). Compared with blank carbon paper, the value of C dl was increased by 7 times with catalysts loaded. However, the C dl of Cu-based catalysts was about 5 times higher than that of pyrolyzed ZIF-L, demonstrating that the Cu doping did increase the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. Moreover, Cu GNC-VL provided abundant electron sources to guarantee transmission of electrons because of the extra capacitance attributed to the electron absorption ability of the vertical structure and distributed Cu/Cu2O. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (d) was used simultaneously. The Nyquist plots revealed a smaller semicircle diameter at low frequencies, explaining that the lower interfacial charge-transfer resistance from the electrodes to electrolyte existed in Cu GNC-VL. To clarify the kinetic activity of CO2 electroreduction, the Tafel slope (b and S11b) was used to reflect the possible intermediate determination steps of the catalytic process. Obviously, the Tafel slope of Cu GNC-VL (313 mV dec–1) was smaller than that of Cu ZIF-L@GO and pyrolyzed ZIF-L. It demonstrated that good kinetics of Cu GNC-VL might promote ethanol generation described as more efficient electron transport and greater active surface area. These electrochemical tests indicated that homogeneous and vertical growth of ZIF-L on GO built a consecutive conductive network and produced more active sites, which is crucial for CO2RR electrocatalysts.
elements.clean_text:
To investigate the electrochemical reduction reaction of
CO2, a series of electrochemical tests were implemented
on the
cathode in an H-type electrolytic cell. The linear sweep voltammetry
(LSV) (a and a) exhibited a more positive onset potential for
Cu GNC-VL (−0.46 V vs RHE) than that of Cu ZIF-L@GO and pyrolyzed
ZIF-L. The Cu contents of Cu ZIF-L@GO (0.522%) and Cu GNC-VL (0.504%)
were measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy.
These catalysts were measured at a similar loading but showed different
catalytic activity. This result was attributed to the synergistic
effect of the composite crystal structure of Cu/Cu2O nanoparticles
embedded in Cu GNC-VL and the highly dispersed particle with efficient
activity and uniform active sites. In b, the partial current density of ethanol
reached 8.69 mA cm–2 at −0.87 V, which was
larger than that of Cu and pyrolyzed ZIF-L. In addition, the relevant
partial current densities of other products listed in Figure S12 also proved that Cu GNC-VL displayed
higher selectivity and charge efficiency. It could be seen that Cu
GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO did exhibit excellent ability to generate hydrocarbons
or alcohols and inhibit the hydrogen evolution reaction, which provided
sufficient conditions for efficiently producing ethanol on Cu GNC-VL.
Encouraged by the improvement of catalytic performance of CO2 electroreduction, we investigated the electrochemical active surface
area (ECSA) of the relevant reaction kinetics of pyrolyzed ZIF-L,
Cu ZIF-L@GO, and Cu GNC-VL. In consideration of the fact that ECSA
is positively correlated with double-layer capacitance (C
dl), the C
dl value was approved
to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the catalysts (C and S9). Compared with blank carbon paper, the value of C
dl was increased by 7 times with catalysts loaded.
However, the C
dl of Cu-based catalysts
was about 5 times higher than that of pyrolyzed ZIF-L, demonstrating
that the Cu doping did increase the intrinsic activity of the catalyst.
Moreover, Cu GNC-VL provided abundant electron sources to guarantee
transmission of electrons because of the extra capacitance attributed
to the electron absorption ability of the vertical structure and distributed
Cu/Cu2O. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (d) was used simultaneously.
The Nyquist plots revealed a smaller semicircle diameter at low frequencies,
explaining that the lower interfacial charge-transfer resistance from
the electrodes to electrolyte existed in Cu GNC-VL. To clarify the kinetic activity of CO2 electroreduction,
the Tafel slope (b and S11b) was used to reflect
the possible intermediate determination steps of the catalytic process.
Obviously, the Tafel slope of Cu GNC-VL (313 mV dec–1) was smaller than that of Cu ZIF-L@GO and pyrolyzed ZIF-L. It demonstrated
that good kinetics of Cu GNC-VL might promote ethanol generation described
as more efficient electron transport and greater active surface area.
These electrochemical tests indicated that homogeneous and vertical
growth of ZIF-L on GO built a consecutive conductive network and produced
more active sites, which is crucial for CO2RR electrocatalysts.

and Cu ZIF-L@GO

elements.content: The resulting products were measured by 1H NMR with water suppression and gas chromatography (Figure S10). The internal standard, dimethylsulfoxide, and phenol were used as references for quantitative calculation (Figure S13). To verify the electrocatalytic performance of carbon dioxide electroreduction, we unified the electrolysis potential from −0.57 to −1.07 V vs RHE (Figure S14a). The FE (c,d and S11a) reflected that the maximum FEethanol of Cu GNC-VL reached 70.52% at −0.87 V vs RHE and FEmethanol of 19.13% at −0.77 V vs RHE. However, the FEethanol decreased to 8.64 and 40.18% for pyrolyzed ZIF-L and Cu ZIF-L@GO, respectively. To prove the stability of the catalyst, the electrolysis experiment was carried out at −0.87 and −0.77 V vs RHE for 12 h on Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO, respectively (Figure S14). The negligible decay of current densities indicated the stability of Cu GNC-VL in the test duration. It is not difficult to find that Cu GNC-VL showed the best physicochemical properties. Good conductivity and a uniformly dispersed active center were the advantages of CO2RR to produce ethanol efficiently. The added two-dimensional semiconductor, GO, not only enhanced the conductivity of the catalyst but also provided chelating sites with Zn2+ for the vertical growth of ZIF-L. However, it is clear that the Cu/Cu2O composite crystal supported on N-doped porous carbon derived from the vertical ZIF-L@GO was essential for Cu GNC-VL to show excellent electrocatalytic performance compared to that of Cu ZIF-L@GO with similar content of Cu. The amorphous Cu/Cu2O inside the Cu GNC-VL catalyst obtained by calcination, on the one hand, achieved reasonable regulation of the distribution of nanoparticles. On the other hand, the loaded nanoparticles also affected the geometric structure of porous carbon, improving the conductive performance of the catalyst. Advantageously, edge and corner sites originating from the amorphous Cu also participated in CO2RR. The declining faradaic efficiency and selectivity of ethanol also proved that Cu(111) (binds to activated CO2) and Cu2O­(111) (dilutes negative 40.18% charge) sites are devoted to the promotion of CO2 activation with favorable kinetics and thermodynamics, and amorphous edge and corner sites on Cu GNC-VL surfaces prompted the C–C coupling.

The resulting products were measured by 1H NMR
with
water suppression and gas chromatography (Figure S10). The internal standard, dimethylsulfoxide, and phenol
were used as references for quantitative calculation (Figure S13). To verify the electrocatalytic performance
of carbon dioxide electroreduction, we unified the electrolysis potential
from −0.57 to −1.07 V vs RHE (Figure S14a). The FE (c,d and S11a) reflected that the
maximum FEethanol of Cu GNC-VL reached 70.52% at −0.87
V vs RHE and FEmethanol of 19.13% at −0.77 V vs
RHE. However, the FEethanol decreased to 8.64 and 40.18%
for pyrolyzed ZIF-L and Cu ZIF-L@GO, respectively. To prove the stability
of the catalyst, the electrolysis experiment was carried out at −0.87
and −0.77 V vs RHE for 12 h on Cu GNC-VL and Cu ZIF-L@GO, respectively
(Figure S14). The negligible decay of current
densities indicated the stability of Cu GNC-VL in the test duration.
It is not difficult to find that Cu GNC-VL showed the best physicochemical
properties. Good conductivity and a uniformly dispersed active center
were the advantages of CO2RR to produce ethanol efficiently.
The added two-dimensional semiconductor, GO, not only enhanced the
conductivity of the catalyst but also provided chelating sites with
Zn2+ for the vertical growth of ZIF-L. However, it is clear
that the Cu/Cu2O composite crystal supported on N-doped
porous carbon derived from the vertical ZIF-L@GO was essential for
Cu GNC-VL to show excellent electrocatalytic performance compared
to that of Cu ZIF-L@GO with similar content of Cu. The amorphous Cu/Cu2O inside the Cu GNC-VL catalyst obtained by calcination, on
the one hand, achieved reasonable regulation of the distribution of
nanoparticles. On the other hand, the loaded nanoparticles also affected
the geometric structure of porous carbon, improving the conductive
performance of the catalyst. Advantageously, edge and corner sites
originating from the amorphous Cu also participated in CO2RR. The declining faradaic efficiency and selectivity of ethanol
also proved that Cu(111) (binds to activated CO2) and Cu2O­(111) (dilutes negative 40.18% charge) sites are devoted
to the promotion of CO2 activation with favorable kinetics
and thermodynamics, and amorphous edge and corner sites on Cu GNC-VL
surfaces prompted the C–C coupling.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized successfully cross-like ZIF-L and vertical ZIF-L on the surface of GO. The homogeneous and vertical growth of GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites exhibited excellent electrical conductivity, high active surface area, and electrocatalytic stability. At −0.87 V vs RHE, Cu GNC-VL exhibited a remarkable FEethanol of 70.52%, with a considerable current density of 10.4 mA cm–2. This work took advantage of the excellent physical and chemical properties of the MOF and exerted the synergistic effect between MOF-derived NPC and GO-derived graphene. GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites with directional structure take another small step forward to convert CO2 into C2 products.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In summary, we synthesized successfully cross-like
ZIF-L and vertical
ZIF-L on the surface of GO. The homogeneous and vertical growth of
GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites exhibited excellent electrical conductivity,
high active surface area, and electrocatalytic stability. At −0.87
V vs RHE, Cu GNC-VL exhibited a remarkable FEethanol of
70.52%, with a considerable current density of 10.4 mA cm–2. This work took advantage of the excellent physical and chemical
properties of the MOF and exerted the synergistic effect between MOF-derived
NPC and GO-derived graphene. GO/ZIF-L nanocomposites with directional
structure take another small step forward to convert CO2 into C2 products.

metadata.title:
Cu/Cu2O Nanoparticles Supported on Vertically
ZIF-L-Coated Nitrogen-Doped Graphene Nanosheets for Electroreduction
of CO2 to Ethanol
